prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AGC252580
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single Band 3 pointing. The goal is to obtain a CO(1-0) map of the target

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In order to put strong constraints on the H2 content of our galaxies and to map their CO distribution we need to detect CO(1-0) emission at, at least, ~10 sigma level in each beam. Since our targets cover a narrow range in redshift and star formation rate, for simplicity all sensitivity estimates are used adopting the average properties of our targets. We have checked that the numbers do not change if the exact redshift and SFR of each object is used.
Our galaxies have a typical SFR surface density 5x10^-3 Msun yr^-1 kpc^-2 which, for the Kennicut-Schmidt law, corresponds to a H2 column density of 15 Msun pc^-2
For a resolution of 1.5 arcsec (~5kpc at z~0.2), the above column density limit corresponds to a a mass of ~4.2x10^8 Msun. Assuming a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 3.2 Msun pc^-2 (K km s^-1 pc^2)^-1 (typical of metal-rich galaxies), this is a CO(1-0) luminosity L_CO = 1.3 x 10^8 = 3.25 x 10^7 x S_CO x nu_obs^-2 x D_L^2 x (1+z)^-3 [K km s^-1 pc^2] (where S_CO is the CO flux density, nu_obs is the observed frequency of the CO line, D_L is the luminosity distance, and z the redshift of the source), and a flux density of 0.067 Jy km/s.
Assuming that the signal is spread over 500 km/s (the typical HI velocity width in our galaxies), this means a flux density of 2.7 mJy for a channel width of 20 km/s. Thus, our 10 sigma limit corresponds to an rms of 0.27 mJy/ beam for a resolution of 20km/s.
We choose 20km/s because our science does not need very high velocity resolution, and this value matches perfectly the resolution of HI and Halpha data already available.
Note that no continuum data are needed for the science associated to this proposal.

The observations proposed here are straightforward. The CO(1-0) line will be observed with Baseband-1 at a velocity resolution of ~3 km/s. Taking into accout that our sensitivity estimate calculation is based on a final channel width of 20km/s, the proposed correlator configuration will allow us to have ~25 resolution elements per line width.
The three remaning basebands will be used for continuum observations simply to put an upper-limit to the continuum emission of our targets. Each baseband will cover 2GHz bandwidth, and will be centered at rest-frame frequency of 115, 128.7 and 131 GHz, respectively.

This project does not have strong imaging requirements. Our main goal is to recover the CO(1-0) flux of the target, determine its extent and morphology, and quantify the kinematics within each beam. A spatial resolution of ~1.5 arcsec corresponds to 5kpc, allowing us to resolve the CO emission (expected to extend up to 15-20" at the very maximum), without the need of the ACA.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to use ALMA to measure the molecular hydrogen content and kinematics of 5 unusually HI-rich galaxies at z~0.2. These are drawn from the HIGHz survey, which includes not only the highest-redshift detections of HI emission to date, but also some of the most HI massive disk galaxies known in the local Universe, with HI-to-stellar mass ratios up to 190%. Despite having huge HI reservoirs and low stellar surface densities, which might be suggestive of giant, inert disks below the threshold for star formation, HIGHz galaxies are forming stars at higher levels than a typical main-sequence galaxy of the same stellar mass. These systems seem to challenge the pressure model for star formation, but are missing the key information on their molecular gas content. With ALMA we will be able to quantify the partition of hydrogen between its atomic and molecular phases, hence gaining crucial insights into the physics that regulates the star formation in the very gas-rich regime that is thought to be more common in the high-redshift Universe.
